shortDescription: The Aqua Tower, located in Chicago, is an iconic skyscraper designed by architect Jeanne Gang of Studio Gang. Completed in 2010, the building is distinguished by its organic, flowing silhouette, characteristic of the blobism movement, with its cascading balconies.
longDescription: The Aqua Tower, situated in Chicago, stands as an iconic skyscraper, a testament to the innovative design prowess of architect Jeanne Gang from Studio Gang. Its completion in 2010 marked a significant contribution to the architectural landscape. The building's distinctive feature lies in its organic and flowing silhouette, a hallmark of the blobism movement. The cascading balconies not only provide a unique aesthetic but also serve as a functional element, creating a dynamic interplay between form and function. The Aqua Tower's design exemplifies a harmonious integration of nature-inspired elements and modern architecture, making it a noteworthy exemplar of the blobism movement and a key player in the evolution of contemporary urban aesthetics.
title: Aqua tower
author: Pierre Antona

shortDescription: The Barbican Centre in London is a cultural and residential complex designed in the Brutalist style, an architectural movement that emerged in the 1950s and 1960s. Designed by architects Chamberlin, Powell and Bon, the Barbican, completed in 1982, remains one of the most emblematic works of Brutalism.
longDescription: The Barbican Centre in London, a cultural and residential complex completed in 1982, stands as an iconic example of Brutalist architecture, a movement that emerged in the 1950s and 1960s. Designed by architects Chamberlin, Powell, and Bon, its bold use of exposed concrete, geometric forms, and emphasis on functionality encapsulate the essence of Brutalism. Beyond its architectural significance, the Barbican Centre serves as a dynamic cultural hub, embodying both the movement's aesthetic principles and functional ideals, contributing significantly to Brutalism's enduring legacy in London's architectural landscape.
title: Barbican Center
author: Kotryna Juskaite

shortDescription: The Lloyd's Building in London is an iconic structure designed by architect Richard Rogers. Completed in 1986, it embodies the high-tech architectural movement. The building is distinguished by its bold use of exposed metal structures, external ventilation ducts and modular design.
longDescription: The Lloyd's Building, a prominent structure in London, stands as a testament to the visionary design of architect Richard Rogers. Completed in 1986, this iconic building is a quintessential representation of the high-tech architectural movement. Its distinguishing features include a bold and innovative use of exposed metal structures, external ventilation ducts, and a modular design. These elements not only contribute to the building's aesthetic appeal but also reflect the movement's core principles of embracing technological advances, functionality, and a futuristic design language. The Lloyd's Building, with its dynamic and technologically expressive form, remains a landmark example of high-tech architecture, showcasing a seamless integration of industrial elements and architectural innovation.
title: Lloyd’s Building
author: Max Whitehead

shortDescription: The Nakagin Capsule Tower in Tokyo, designed by architect Kisho Kurokawa in 1972, is an emblematic figure of the metabolist movement. This modular tower expresses the Japanese metabolic vision by integrating interchangeable prefabricated capsules, symbolizing the idea of organic growth and constant adaptability in architectural design.
longDescription: The Nakagin Capsule Tower in Tokyo, designed by architect Kisho Kurokawa in 1972, is an emblematic example of the metabolist movement. Founded in Japan in the 1960s, architectural metabolism adopts an organic, evolutionary vision of urban design. This modular tower perfectly represents this philosophy, incorporating interchangeable prefabricated capsules, symbolizing the idea of organic growth and constant adaptability in architectural design. The metabolic approach, exemplified by the Nakagin Capsule Tower, aims to create flexible, evolving urban environments, reflecting the movement's forward-looking vision of dynamic, ever-changing urban development. Kurokawa's innovative design, marked by its modular elements, positions this tower as a symbol of the metabolist movement's commitment to envisioning cities as dynamic and ever-evolving entities.
title: Nakagin Capsule Tower
author: Arthur Mazi

shortDescription: The Brazilian National Congress, located in Brasilia, is an emblematic building designed by architect Oscar Niemeyer as part of the urban plan for Brazil's new capital, completed in 1960. It is a landmark work of the modernist movement.
longDescription: The Brazilian National Congress, located in Brasília, is an iconic creation by architect Oscar Niemeyer, part of the city's 1960 urban plan. Completed in 1960, it stands as a landmark of modernist architecture, characterized by clean lines and geometric simplicity. Niemeyer's design reflects the movement's commitment to progress, functionality, and a departure from traditional ornamentation, making the Brazilian National Congress a significant symbol of modernity within Brasília and the broader global modernist movement.
title: Brazilian National Congress
author: Gustavo Leighton
